data.text/markdown: Chapter 4: Implementing a GPT model from Scratch To Generate Text
4.1 Coding an LLM architecture

console.name: stdout
console.text:
matplotlib version: 3.10.8
torch version: 2.9.1+cu128
tiktoken version: 0.12.0

data.text/markdown: This is hyperparameters of our GPT-2 model.
This is placeholder architecture for our GPT2 model. The placeholders will be replaced. The "Dummy" means simple model by using simple placeholders just to check forward path algorithms.
Use GPT2 embedding and create a batch contains two phrases
Randomly initialize the GPT2:1.24b model and inference logits with untrained weights. The output is called as logits, and the shape is (batch_size,seq_len,vocab_size).
4.2 Normalizing activations with layer normalization
To get efficient gradients for training, introduce layer normalization. Let's use the following usual linear+ReLU layer to check the effect of layer normalization.
Check statistics before normalization.

console.name: stdout
console.text:
Mean:
 tensor([[0.1324],
        [0.2170]], grad_fn=<MeanBackward1>)
Variance:
 tensor([[0.0231],
        [0.0398]], grad_fn=<VarBackward0>)

data.text/markdown: Apply normalization to that.
Disable PyTorch scientific notation for readability

console.name: stdout
console.text:
Mean: tensor([[0.0000],
        [0.0000]], grad_fn=<MeanBackward1>)
Variance: tensor([[1.0000],
        [1.0000]], grad_fn=<VarBackward0>)

data.text/markdown: To replace the layer norm placeholder, implement LayerNorm class based on the above observations. The normalization is applied to the last dimension emb_dim, and scaling and shift parameters are introduced to learn suitable distribution for good gradients.
Try it.

console.name: stdout
console.text:
Mean:
 tensor([[-0.0000],
        [ 0.0000]], grad_fn=<MeanBackward1>)
Variance:
 tensor([[1.0000],
        [1.0000]], grad_fn=<VarBackward0>)

data.text/markdown: 4.3 Implementing a feed forward network with GELU activations

We use GELU (Gaussian Error Linear Unit) as an activation function. This is defined as $$ \mathrm{GELU}(x)\equiv x\cdot\Phi(x),\quad \Phi(x)\equiv\int dx\,\mathcal{N}(x;\mu=0,\sigma=1) $$ Because of efficiency, we use the following approximation obtained by curve fitting. $$ \text{GELU}(x) \approx 0.5 \cdot x \cdot \left(1 + \tanh\left[\sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi}} \cdot \left(x + 0.044715 \cdot x^3\right)\right]\right) $$ This GELU is known as smoother gradient and better activation function than ReLU for learning.
Compare GELU with ReLU. GERU has non-zero gradient except for certain point, so it avoids singular optimizations. GELU also accepts minus ||(x||) and such values also contribute the training.
This is the class for FeedForward network using GELU.
Remind embedding dimension of our GPT2.

This shows the output shape of the FeedForward network. The first layer increses the dimension in 4 times, then, the last layer decreases the dimension to the same with the input. This makes GPT2 model deeper without considering input/output dimesion compatibilities.

console.name: stdout
console.text: torch.Size([2, 3, 768])

data.text/markdown: 4.4 Adding shortcut connections
This is an example of skip connection like ResNet. To avoid vanishing gradient problem of deep networks, this network predicts residuals in each steps.
To see the vanishing gradient problem, define the following function to see gradients.
You can see vanishing gradients from the last layer 4 to the initial layer 0.

console.name: stdout
console.text:
layers.0.0.weight has gradient mean of 0.00020173587836325169
layers.1.0.weight has gradient mean of 0.00012011159560643137
layers.2.0.weight has gradient mean of 0.0007152040489017963
layers.3.0.weight has gradient mean of 0.0013988736318424344
layers.4.0.weight has gradient mean of 0.005049645435065031

data.text/markdown: Skip connection relaxes the problem like this.

console.name: stdout
console.text:
layers.0.0.weight has gradient mean of 0.22169798612594604
layers.1.0.weight has gradient mean of 0.20694111287593842
layers.2.0.weight has gradient mean of 0.3289700150489807
layers.3.0.weight has gradient mean of 0.26657330989837646
layers.4.0.weight has gradient mean of 1.3258544206619263

data.text/markdown: 4.5 Connecting attention and linear layers in a transformer block
Implement TransformerBlock by including the above ideas of MultiHeadAttention, FeedForward and LayerNorm.
It keeps the shape of vectors between inputs and outputs. It is suitable to combine deep layers.

console.name: stdout
console.text:
Input shape: torch.Size([2, 4, 768])
Output shape: torch.Size([2, 4, 768])

data.text/markdown: 4.6 Coding the GPT model
Replace the placeholders in Dummy class to create GPT2 model. It repeats TransformerBlock in n_layers times. The output logits represents unnormalized probabilities for next tokens.
Try the forward path. The output shape is (B,num_tokens,d_out).
We can get total number of parameters by numel() method.

console.name: stdout
console.text: Total number of parameters: 163,009,536

data.text/markdown: We can share token embedding weights and output layer weights if you hope. These has the same shape.

console.name: stdout
console.text:
Token embedding layer shape: torch.Size([50257, 768])
Output layer shape: torch.Size([50257, 768])

data.text/markdown: By considering such weight sharing, this model parameters reduces to 1.24b parameters.

console.name: stdout
console.text: Number of trainable parameters considering weight tying: 124,412,160

data.text/markdown: We can estimate memory size to load this model by this.

console.name: stdout
console.text: Total size of the model: 621.83 MB

data.text/markdown: 4.7 Generating text

This is a function to generate texts (decoding) from GPT2 outputs. The step applies softmax can be omitted because it is monotonic. It is called as the greedy decoding to select tokens whose probability is the maximum on the candidates. There are several strategies to select next tokens according to tasks.
Encode texts by using tokenizer to prepare the input.

console.name: stdout
console.text:
encoded: [15496, 11, 314, 716]
encoded_tensor.shape: torch.Size([1, 4])

data.text/markdown: Input it to the function to generate text. The output is token IDs.
Decode the output token IDs by using tokenizer. The output is nonsense because we did not train it yet.

console.name: stdout
console.text: Hello, I am Featureiman Byeswickattribute argue
